prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J091840.8_[NII] 122 um
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Line Intensity = 61 Jy-km/s BIN = 50 km/s SNR peak = 50 Beam size = 0.3

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We base the line flux estimate on the observed FIR continuum scaled so that [NII] 205/FIR = 0.03% as found in nearby galaxies. The peak line intensity is obtained by assuming the line is a Gaussian of FWHM = 300 km/s, then sampling the central 50 km/s wide spectral bin. This central bin contains 20% of the total line flux. The sensitivity is selected so as to detect the line in the central bin at SNR = 300 in the [NII] 205 um line. The SNR improves by about a factor of two integrating over the whole line profile. We set the angular resolution to 0.2” so that assuming the source is extended over a 1” (8 kpc) region, the average flux per beam is 25 times smaller than the total line flux. Therefore, within each beam, we expect SNR ~ 300/25*2 = 24 – more than ample to meet our science requirements.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SMM J02399_[CII]
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Line Intensity = 301 Jy-km/s BIN = 50 km/s SNR peak = 200 Beam size = 0.2 noise = 4.17 mJy

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We base the line flux estimate on the observed FIR continuum scaled so that [CII] 205/FIR = 0.3% as found in nearby galaxies. The peak line intensity is obtained by assuming the line is a Gaussian of FWHM = 300 km/s, then sampling the central 50 km/s wide spectral bin. This central bin contains 20% of the total line flux. The sensitivity is selected so as to detect the line in the central bin at SNR > 500 in the [CII] 158 um line. The SNR improves by about a factor of two integrating over the whole line profile. We set the angular resolution to 0.2” so that assuming the source is extended over a 1” (8 kpc) region, the average flux per beam is 25 times smaller than the total line flux. Therefore, within each beam, we expect SNR > 500/25*2 = 40 – more than ample to meet our science requirements.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SMM J0299_[NII] 122
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Line Intensity = 161 Jy-km/s BIN = 50 km/s SNR peak = 100 Beam size = 0.3 Noise = 4.47

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We base the line flux estimate on the observed [CII] line flux in Ferkinhoff et al. 2011. The peak line intensity is obtained by assuming the line is a Gaussian of FWHM = 300 km/s, then sampling the central 50 km/s wide spectral bin. This central bin contains 20% of the total line flux. The sensitivity is selected so as to detect the line in the central bin at SNR =100 in the [NII] 122 um line. The SNR improves by about a factor of two integrating over the whole line profile. We set the angular resolution to 0.3” so that assuming the source is extended over a 1” (8 kpc) region, the average flux per beam is 10 times smaller than the total line flux. Therefore, within each beam, we expect SNR ~ 100/10*2 = 20 – more than ample to meet our science requirements.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose an ALMA survey of 6 z~3 galaxies in the [NII] and [CII] lines. Our [CII] work revealed that star formation is very extended in z~1-2 systems – likely driven by Schmidt-Kennicutt law star formation in massive “disks” that grow by cold accretion – very different from local ULIRGs. We also showed how the [NII] 122 line traces HII region mass and N(LyC), hence the number of OB stars. Our ALMA [CII]/[NII] work will directly resolve the starburst, addressing the question: What is the relative importance of cold accretion and major merger in stimulating star formation over cosmic time? This program is enhanced by planned April 2014 ZEUS-2/APEX observations of these sources in the [OIII] 88 µm line. Our [NII] 122 µm/[OIII] 88 µm work showed that the line ratio is a powerful tracer of the hardness of stellar radiation fields, which translates into the most massive star on the main sequence, or the stellar population age. The combination of these four lines then addresses the question: What are the most massive stars on the main sequence as a function of cosmic time? Do changes reflect main sequence age, or changes in star formation mode, or in the initial mass function?
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2013.1.00400.S (PI C. Ferkinhoff) pursues some of the same science at higher (z > 4.4 ) redshifts 2013.0039.S (PI D. Brisbin) pursues related science (abundances at z > 4) .
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00596.S -- rolled over into Cycle 2; 2012.1.00426.S -- also rolled over into Cycle 2; 2011.1.00747.S, 2011.1.00742.S -- very litlittle quality data was obtrained for either of these Cycle 0, Band 9 proposals.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University
